description: Why would i ever use this

I think the reality of the world is that all software platforms require some type of moderation and control tool. I'm happy to see that one is provided by Gnome. That being said, it isn't there yet. It's quite limited in functionality. Currently, it appears that the app is only able to restrict access to Flatpak applications, making it useless for anyone that has installed RPMs. It also appears that you are unable to restrict which web browsers someone has access to, only restrict access to web browsers generally. There's also no functionality to restrict what type of content a user sees, so don't rely on this app if you would like to limit access to adult content on a device. Compared to other moderation apps from the likes of Apple or Google, this comes short. The fact it exists does give me hope that someday there will be a moderation app that is up to the level of functionality of something like iOS, which would be my hope.
summary: Not useless, but not there yet

description:
0/5
I'm a 40 years old man... no kids.
I do not need a "Parental Control" app.
I did not asked for this to be installed by default.
Plus there is no possibility to remove it.
Gnome is becoming more and more full of bloat.
I don't know how to use it at all. Most of the time it's not needed but certainly the idea is good. There should be a way to easily remove this tool if it is not needed.

Doesn't actually prevent a user from launching an app. Just hides it in GNOME Desktop.

- Launching via Terminal still works
- If the user uses a different desktop enviroment, the app is visible as if it weren't blocked. And it also still launches.

All in all, great idea. I'm okay with it being installed by default, but an uninstall option would be nice - if at all possible.
summary: Only blocks things launched through GNOME
